articles.title: Hidden for 70 million years, a tiny fossil fish is rewriting freshwater evolution
articles.summary: Researchers in Alberta uncovered a fossil fish that rewrites the evolutionary history of otophysans, which today dominate freshwater ecosystems. The new species, Acronichthys maccognoi, shows early adaptations for its unusual hearing system. Evidence suggests otophysans moved from oceans to rivers more than once, leaving scientists puzzled about their ancient global journeys.
articles.content:
The fossil of a tiny fish found in southwestern Alberta provides new insight into the origin and evolution of otophysans, the supergroup of fish that includes catfish, carp and tetras, which today account for two-thirds of all freshwater species.

The specimen, studied by researchers at Western University, the Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology and international collaborators, is a skeleton of a fish about 4 cm long from the Late Cretaceous period (the age of the iconic Tyrannosaurus Rex, about 100.5 million to 66 million years ago.) A new kind of fish entirely, it is now named Acronichthys maccognoi.

A study detailing the discovery was published on October 2 in the high impact journal, Science.

"The reason Acronichthys is so exciting is that it fills a gap in our record of the otophysans supergroup. It is the oldest North America member of the group and provides incredible data to help document the origin and early evolution of so many freshwater fish living today," said Neil Banerjee, Earth sciences professor and author on the study.

Banerjee collaborated with an international team including Lisa Van Loon, adjunct Earth sciences professor at Western, Don Brinkman, curator emeritus at the Royal Tyrell Museum, Juan Liu from the University of California, Berkeley and Alison Murray from the University of Alberta.

Otophysans are distinctive in the way the first four vertebrae are modified to transmit vibrations to the ear from the swim bladder (a gas-filled internal organ that allows fish to maintain their position in the water without expending significant energy), basically functioning as a human ear. This is easily spotted in the skeleton of the found fossil of Acronichthys by the naked eye. Van Loon, using synchrotron beamlines at both the Canadian Light Source in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, and the Advanced Photon Source in Lemont, Illinois, captured a more sophisticated, detailed look with computed tomography (micro-CT) scans.

Micro-CT scans are non-destructive (critical when studying prehistoric fossils), high-resolution X-ray images that create 3D virtual models of objects by taking a series of 2D X-ray projections as an object, in this case the Acronichthys, rotates.

"Many of the fossil specimens collected by the Royal Tyrrell Museum are incredibly fragile, and some are impossible to extract from the rock itself, so micro-CT scans provide not only the best method for acquiring detailed images of what's inside, they're also the safest way to avoid destroying the fossil all together," said Van Loon.

One fish, two fish, red fish, blue fish

While the discovery of Acronichthys introduces a new species to paleontological records, it also provides critical data to trace the origins of otophysans, as the supergroup is understood to have started as a marine (saltwater) species before transitioning to a freshwater species. The discovery suggests the transition from marine to freshwater species happened at least twice during otophysans' evolution.

The study estimated a new divergence time for otophysans from marine to freshwater species at around 154 million years ago (the Late Jurassic period) - after Pangea, the supercontinent, began to break apart about 200 million years ago. The researchers are left trying to understand how the tiny Acronichthys moved from continent to continent (as its freshwater ancestors now live on every continent except Antarctica) if they couldn't swim across saltwater oceans.

"Dinosaurs are pretty exciting, so a lot of time and effort has been focused on them so we know a lot about what they were like, but we've only scratched the surface when it comes to understanding the diversity of prehistoric freshwater fish," said Brinkman. "There's still so much we don't know, and a fossil site right here in Canada is giving us the key to understanding the origins of groups that now dominate rivers and lakes around the world."
articles.reasoning: The discovery of the fossil fish Acronichthys maccognoi provides significant new scientific insight into the evolutionary history of freshwater fish, revealing multiple marine-to-freshwater transitions and filling a major gap in paleontological knowledge. The detailed study using advanced micro-CT scanning technology highlights a meaningful breakthrough in understanding biodiversity and evolutionary biology with broad implications for science and education.
articles.personality_title: Fossil fish found in Canada sheds light on freshwater fish evolution
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study otophysans, a large group of fish that includes catfish and tetras, which make up most freshwater fish today. Understanding their early history helps explain how freshwater ecosystems developed.

**What happened** – Researchers in Alberta discovered a tiny fossil fish named Acronichthys maccognoi from around 70 million years ago. Using special 3D X-ray scans called micro-CT, they examined its skeleton and found early features linked to how these fish hear underwater.

**Impact** – This fossil is the oldest otophysan found in North America and shows that these fish switched from living in the ocean to freshwater rivers more than once. This challenges previous ideas and helps explain how freshwater fish spread across continents.

**What's next step** – Scientists will continue studying fossils and use new technologies to learn more about how freshwater fish evolved and moved between continents long ago.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The discovery of Acronichthys maccognoi offers fresh clues about the ancient journeys and evolution of fish that now dominate rivers worldwide.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un poisson fossile découvert au Canada éclaire l'évolution des poissons d'eau douce
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient les otophysaires, un grand groupe de poissons comprenant les silures et les tétras, qui représentent la majorité des poissons d'eau douce aujourd'hui. Comprendre leur histoire ancienne aide à expliquer le développement des écosystèmes d'eau douce.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs en Alberta ont découvert un petit poisson fossile nommé Acronichthys maccognoi datant d'environ 70 millions d'années. Grâce à des scans 3D spéciaux appelés micro-CT, ils ont examiné son squelette et trouvé des caractéristiques précoces liées à la façon dont ces poissons entendent sous l'eau.

**Impact** – Ce fossile est le plus ancien otophysaure trouvé en Amérique du Nord et montre que ces poissons sont passés de la vie marine à l'eau douce plus d'une fois. Cela remet en question les idées précédentes et aide à comprendre comment les poissons d'eau douce se sont répandus sur plusieurs continents.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont continuer à étudier les fossiles et utiliser de nouvelles technologies pour mieux comprendre l'évolution et les déplacements anciens des poissons d'eau douce.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La découverte d'Acronichthys maccognoi apporte de nouveaux indices sur les voyages anciens et l'évolution des poissons qui dominent aujourd'hui les rivières du monde entier.
articles.personality_title_es: Pez fósil hallado en Canadá revela la evolución de los peces de agua dulce
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian a los otófisidos, un gran grupo de peces que incluye bagres y tetras, que representan la mayoría de los peces de agua dulce hoy en día. Entender su historia temprana ayuda a explicar cómo se desarrollaron los ecosistemas de agua dulce.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores en Alberta descubrieron un pequeño pez fósil llamado Acronichthys maccognoi de hace unos 70 millones de años. Usando escaneos especiales en 3D llamados micro-CT, examinaron su esqueleto y encontraron características tempranas relacionadas con cómo estos peces oyen bajo el agua.

**Impacto** – Este fósil es el otófisido más antiguo encontrado en América del Norte y muestra que estos peces pasaron de vivir en el océano a ríos de agua dulce más de una vez. Esto desafía ideas anteriores y ayuda a explicar cómo los peces de agua dulce se extendieron por los continentes.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán estudiando fósiles y usando nuevas tecnologías para aprender más sobre cómo evolucionaron y se desplazaron los peces de agua dulce hace mucho tiempo.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El descubrimiento de Acronichthys maccognoi ofrece nuevas pistas sobre los antiguos viajes y la evolución de los peces que hoy dominan los ríos del mundo.

articles.title: How China is challenging Nvidia's AI chip dominance
articles.summary: Beijing has urged local firms to use homemade chips. But is China ready to turn away from Nvidia?
articles.content:
How China is challenging Nvidia's AI chip dominance

5 hours ago Share Save Osmond Chia Business reporter Share Save

Getty Images Jensen Huang, the boss of Silicon Valley-based Nvidia, has warned China is "nanoseconds behind" the US in chips

The US has dominated the global technology market for decades. But China wants to change that. The world's second largest economy is pouring huge amounts of money into artificial intelligence (AI) and robotics. Crucially, Beijing is also investing heavily to produce the high-end chips that power these cutting-edge technologies. Last month, Jensen Huang - the boss of Silicon Valley-based AI chip giant Nvidia - warned that China was just "nanoseconds behind" the US in chip development. So can Beijing match American technology and break its reliance on imported high-end chips?

After DeepSeek

China's DeepSeek sent shockwaves through the tech world in 2024 when it launched a rival to OpenAI's ChatGPT. The announcement by a relatively unknown startup was impressive for a number of reasons, not least because the company said it cost much less to train than leading AI models. It was said to have been created using far fewer high-end chips than its rivals, and its launch temporarily sank Silicon Valley-based Nvidia's market value. And momentum in China's tech sector has continued. This year, some of the country's big tech firms have made it clear that they aim to take on Nvidia and become the main advanced chip suppliers for local companies. In September, Chinese state media said a new chip announced by Alibaba can match the performance of Nvidia's H20 semiconductors while using less energy. H20s are scaled-down processors made for the Chinese market under US export rules. Huawei also unveiled what it said were its most powerful chips ever, along with a three-year plan to challenge Nvidia's dominance of the AI market. The Chinese tech giant also said it would make its designs and computer programs available to the public in China in an effort to draw firms away from their reliance on US products.

Getty Images DeepSeek stunned the tech world in 2024 when it launched an AI model to rival ChatGPT

Other Chinese chip developers have also secured major contracts with big businesses in the country. MetaX is supplying advanced chips for the likes of state-owned telecoms operator, China Unicom. Another hotly-tipped potential challenger to Nvidia is Beijing-based Cambricon Technologies. Its Shanghai-listed shares have more than doubled in value over the last three months as investors bet that it will benefit from Beijing's push for Chinese firms to use locally produced high-end chips. Tencent, which owns the super app WeChat, is another notable tech giant that has heeded the government’s call to use Chinese chips. There has also been no shortage of state-backed trade shows, promoting Chinese technology companies in a bid to attract investors. "The competition has undeniably arrived," a spokesperson for Nvidia told the BBC in response to queries about the recent progress made by Chinese chip firms. "Customers will choose the best technology stack for running the world's most popular commercial applications and open-source models. We'll continue to work to earn the trust and support of mainstream developers everywhere." Yet some experts have cautioned that claims made by Chinese chipmakers should be taken with a pinch of salt due to a lack of publicly available data and consistent testing benchmarks. China's semiconductors perform similarly to the US in predictive AI but fall short in complex analytics, said computer scientist Jawad Haj-Yahya, who has tested both American and Chinese chips. "The gap is clear and it is surely shrinking. But I don't think it's something they will catch up on in the short-term."

Where China leads - and lags

On the BG2 technology and business podcast in September, Nvidia's Jensen Huang highlighted the strengths of China's tech sector, crediting its hardworking and vast talent pool, intense domestic competition and progress in chipmaking. "This is a vibrant entrepreneurial, high-tech, modern industry," he said, urging the US to compete "for its survival". His assessment is likely to be welcomed by officials in Beijing. The country has long vied to become a global leader in tech, partly to reduce its reliance on the West. For years, China has invested heavily in what President Xi Jinping calls "high-quality development", which covers industries from renewables to AI. Even before US President Donald Trump's return to the White House, China had spent tens of billions of dollars as part of its efforts to transform its vast economy from the "world's factory" for basic products to a home of cutting-edge industries. An ongoing tariffs war with Trump's America has only made that mission more urgent. Xi has vowed to make his country more self-reliant and not depend on "anyone's gifts".

Mr Huang has also warned that the US should trade freely with China or risk handing it the edge in the AI race. This comes against a backdrop of Beijing applying more pressure on Nvidia as it launched an anti-monopoly probe into the firm last month. But China's state-led approach can also be an obstacle to innovation if everyone in the sector only focuses on a "shared goal", said computing professor Chia-Lin Yang from the National Taiwan University. It can make it harder for disruptive ideas to break the mould, she added. China's chip industry has also yet to overcome criticism that its products can be less user-friendly than those of Western rivals like Nvidia. Prof Yang believes these issues can soon be solved by China's huge number of skilled tech industry workers. "You cannot underestimate China's ability to catch up."

Getty Images Chinese tech giant Huawei unveiled its plans to rival Nvidia's dominance in AI chips

'Bargaining chip' for China
articles.reasoning: The article reports on China's significant progress and investment in developing advanced AI chips to challenge Nvidia's dominance, reflecting a major technological breakthrough with broad implications for global tech competition and innovation. It highlights tangible advancements by multiple Chinese companies, government support, and potential for reducing reliance on foreign technology, which is inspiring and impactful on a large scale.
articles.personality_title: China steps up to challenge Nvidia’s lead in AI chips
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For many years, the United States, with companies like Nvidia, has led the world in making powerful computer chips used in artificial intelligence (AI). China, a big economic power, wants to catch up and make its own advanced chips to reduce reliance on foreign technology.

**What happened** – In 2024, Chinese companies like DeepSeek, Alibaba, Huawei, and Cambricon Technologies made important progress in creating AI chips that can compete with Nvidia’s products. For example, Alibaba announced a chip that matches Nvidia’s performance but uses less energy. Huawei shared its strongest chips yet and plans to share designs to help other Chinese companies. These efforts come with strong support from the Chinese government and interest from big local businesses.

**Impact** – This progress is important because it shows China is closing the gap in AI chip technology. Chinese chips now perform well in some AI tasks, and the country’s large talent pool and investments help speed up development. It could change the global tech market by offering more choices and reducing dependence on US-made chips. However, experts say China still has some way to go in complex AI tasks and user-friendly designs.

**What’s next step** – Chinese companies will continue improving their chips and trying to win more business at home and abroad. The Chinese government is likely to keep supporting this goal. Meanwhile, Nvidia plans to keep competing by offering strong technology and working closely with developers worldwide. How this competition unfolds will affect future AI technology and global trade relations.

**One-sentence takeaway** – China is making clear strides in advanced AI chips, challenging Nvidia’s dominance and reshaping the global technology race.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Chine intensifie ses efforts pour concurrencer Nvidia dans les puces d’IA
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis longtemps, les États-Unis, avec des entreprises comme Nvidia, dominent la fabrication des puces informatiques puissantes utilisées en intelligence artificielle (IA). La Chine, une grande puissance économique, souhaite rattraper son retard et produire ses propres puces avancées pour moins dépendre de la technologie étrangère.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2024, des entreprises chinoises comme DeepSeek, Alibaba, Huawei et Cambricon Technologies ont fait des progrès importants pour créer des puces d’IA capables de rivaliser avec celles de Nvidia. Par exemple, Alibaba a présenté une puce qui offre des performances comparables à celles de Nvidia tout en consommant moins d’énergie. Huawei a dévoilé ses puces les plus puissantes et prévoit de partager ses plans pour aider d’autres sociétés chinoises. Ces efforts sont soutenus fortement par le gouvernement chinois et attirent l’attention de grandes entreprises locales.

**Impact** – Ces avancées sont importantes car elles montrent que la Chine réduit l’écart en technologie des puces d’IA. Les puces chinoises fonctionnent bien pour certaines tâches d’IA, et le grand nombre de talents et les investissements du pays accélèrent les progrès. Cela pourrait changer le marché mondial de la technologie en offrant plus de choix et en diminuant la dépendance aux puces américaines. Cependant, des experts notent que la Chine doit encore progresser pour les tâches d’IA complexes et pour des designs plus faciles à utiliser.

**Prochaine étape** – Les entreprises chinoises vont continuer à améliorer leurs puces et à chercher à gagner plus de parts de marché en Chine et à l’étranger. Le gouvernement chinois devrait continuer à soutenir cet objectif. De son côté, Nvidia compte rester compétitif en offrant une technologie performante et en travaillant avec les développeurs du monde entier. Cette compétition influencera l’avenir de la technologie IA et les relations commerciales mondiales.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La Chine progresse nettement dans les puces d’IA avancées, défiant la domination de Nvidia et transformant la course mondiale à la technologie.
articles.personality_title_es: China acelera para desafiar el liderazgo de Nvidia en chips de IA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante muchos años, Estados Unidos, con empresas como Nvidia, ha liderado el mundo en la fabricación de chips potentes usados en inteligencia artificial (IA). China, una gran potencia económica, quiere alcanzar a Estados Unidos y producir sus propios chips avanzados para depender menos de tecnología extranjera.

**Qué pasó** – En 2024, empresas chinas como DeepSeek, Alibaba, Huawei y Cambricon Technologies lograron avances importantes en la creación de chips de IA que pueden competir con los de Nvidia. Por ejemplo, Alibaba presentó un chip que iguala el rendimiento de Nvidia pero consume menos energía. Huawei mostró sus chips más potentes y planea compartir sus diseños para ayudar a otras compañías chinas. Estos esfuerzos cuentan con fuerte apoyo del gobierno chino y el interés de grandes empresas locales.

**Impacto** – Estos avances son importantes porque muestran que China está reduciendo la distancia en tecnología de chips de IA. Los chips chinos funcionan bien en algunas tareas de IA, y la gran cantidad de talentos e inversiones del país aceleran el desarrollo. Esto podría cambiar el mercado tecnológico global al ofrecer más opciones y reducir la dependencia de chips fabricados en EE.UU. Sin embargo, expertos indican que China aún tiene que mejorar en tareas complejas de IA y en diseños más fáciles de usar.

**Próximo paso** – Las empresas chinas seguirán mejorando sus chips y buscando ganar más clientes dentro y fuera del país. Es probable que el gobierno chino siga apoyando este objetivo. Mientras tanto, Nvidia planea seguir compitiendo ofreciendo tecnología fuerte y colaborando con desarrolladores en todo el mundo. Esta competencia influirá en el futuro de la tecnología IA y en las relaciones comerciales globales.

**Resumen en una frase** – China avanza claramente en chips avanzados de IA, desafiando el dominio de Nvidia y cambiando la carrera tecnológica mundial.
